t: How*pn beautiful you are, my darling. How*ln very beautiful! Behind*ln your veil, your*ln eyes are doves. Your*ln hair is like a flock of goats streaming*ln down Mount Gilead.
Your*ln teeth are like a flock of newly shorn sheep coming*ln up from washing, each*ln one bearing twins, and*ln none has lost its young.
Your*ln lips are like a scarlet cord, and*ln your mouth is lovely. Behind*ln your veil, your*ln brow is like a slice of pomegranate.
Your*ln neck is like the tower of David, constructed*ln in layers. A*ln thousand shields are hung on it — all*ln of them shields of warriors.
Your*ln breasts are like two fawns, twins*ln of a gazelle, that feed among the lilies.
Until*ln the day breaks and*ln the shadows flee, I*ln will make my way to the mountain of myrrh and*ln the hill of frankincense.
You*ln are absolutely beautiful, my darling; there*ln is no imperfection in you.

Come*pn with me from Lebanon, my bride; come*ln with me from Lebanon! Descend*ln from the peak of Amana, from*ln the summit of Senir and Hermon, from*ln the dens of the lions, from*ln the mountains of the leopards.
You*ln have captured my heart, my sister, my bride. You*ln have captured my heart with one glance of your eyes, with*ln one jewel of your necklace.
How*ln delightful your caresses are, my sister, my bride. Your*ln caresses are much better than wine, and*ln the fragrance of your perfume than any balsam.
Your*ln lips drip sweetness like the honeycomb, my bride. Honey*ln and milk are under your tongue. The*ln fragrance of your garments is like the fragrance of Lebanon.
My*pn sister, my bride, you are a locked garden — a*ln locked garden and a sealed spring.
Your*ln branches are a paradise of pomegranates with*ln choicest fruits; henna*ln with nard,
nard*ln and saffron, calamus and cinnamon, with*ln all the trees of frankincense, myrrh*ln and aloes, with*ln all the best spices.
You*ln are a garden spring, a*ln well of flowing water streaming*ln from Lebanon.
Awaken,*pn north wind; come,*ln south wind. Blow*ln on my garden, and*ln spread the fragrance of its spices. Let*ln my love come to his garden and*ln eat its choicest fruits.
